qas.question: Which tense indicates that an action hasn't finished?
Which two states do Shtokavian verbs have?
When is the perspective aspect of a verb used?

answers.text: action was completed, instantaneous, or of limited duration

qas.question: What are two aspects the Kajkavian verb has?
What do prefixes come in usually?
What is the stem change created out of?
What do some Shtokavian verbs favor?
What do limited duration actions compensate for?

context: In addition, like most Slavic languages, the Shtokavian verb also has one of two aspects: <a1_0><b3_0>perfective or imperfective<b3_0/><a1_0/>. Most verbs come in <b4_0>pairs<b4_0/>, with the perfective verb being created out of <b5_0>the imperfective<b5_0/> by adding a prefix or making a stem change. The <a0_0>imperfective<a0_0/> aspect typically indicates that the action is unfinished, in progress, or repetitive; while the perfective aspect typically denotes that the <a2_0>action was completed, instantaneous, or of limited duration<a2_0/>. Some Štokavian tenses (namely, aorist and imperfect) favor <b6_0>a particular aspect<b6_0/> (but they are rarer or absent in Čakavian and Kajkavian). Actually, aspects "compensate" for <b7_0>the relative lack of tenses<b7_0/>, because aspect of the verb determines whether the act is completed or in progress in the referred time.
